The Mexican government sent out pictures last night showing Guzman dressed in tan prison garb accompanied by many Mexican police.
They also showed pictures of him then in the custody of the U.S.
DEA agents and boarding that plane.
U.S.
officials say he landed in Long Island, N.Y., last night, and today they'll announce plans for his arraignment.
Remind us who is El Chapo?
He's a legend in Mexico, right?
He definitely is.
He grew up very poor and started in the family business very young.
He climbed the ranks of the drug trafficking syndicate very quickly despite not having more than a sixth grade education, they always say.
He's believed to be a billionaire and the head of this cartel, the Sinaloa Cartel, which is one of the most powerful in the world, and it has cells throughout the world.
Many a Narco ballad, the songs about the drug traffickers, have been written about Chapo's supposed generosity back in his home state.
But don't ever forget that this man is responsible for unspeakable murder, torture and violence throughout Mexico and beyond and despite some of his glorification in the press.
But the best part about Chapo to talk about is his notorious great escapes, and he made two - the latest in the summer of 2015.
That was the most daring and amazing.
It was through a tunnel that began in his prison cell shower, dropped down to a tunnel that ran a mile long.
He jumped on a modified motorcycle and went through that mile-long tunnel and out to freedom.
And he was on the run for about six months.
And during that time, he had that secret meeting with Mexican star Kate del Castillo and actor Sean Penn.
Yeah.
And in some way, that led to his downfall.
Mexican officials say that he was captured after they caught up with him hearing about this clandestine meeting.
And he was captured, but not before he almost escaped from a safe house through a tunnel.
So why now?
Why would Mexico have decided to extradite him now?
That is the big question, and it's lots of speculation.
And I don't have the answer to that.

But I can tell you what some of the speculations were is what - that the Mexicans wanted to give him over to the United States while President Obama was still in power, not to President Trump today, but also maybe that this was a signal to President Trump that they are ready to negotiate, and this was their prize to him on his first day in office.
What charges will he face in the U.S.?

officials say there are six separate indictments in courts throughout the United States.
He's up for murder, drug trafficking, money laundering, use of firearms.
He's got a lot of charges, and the first one up is the federal court in New York.
And just briefly, what - is there a larger significance here?
I mean, he was so important in the drug trade in North America.
What does it mean for the so-called War on Drugs?
It has a lot of significance.
El Chapo represents, in some ways, the failure of the War on Drugs.
There is just this large drug market in the U.S.
You know, even with his capture and his being extradited to the U.S., the drug war rages on.
In Mexico, violence levels are as high as they were four years ago, and there probably will be little impact on the drug war with his capture.
NPR's Carrie Kahn in Mexico City.
Thanks, Carrie.

A young Nicaraguan man is in hiding in Toronto because he is afraid to go back home.
Alvaro Orozco is also afraid to show his face in Canada because he's there illegally.
Now, this may not seem all that extraordinary until we tell you why Orozco fears returning to Nicaragua and why he can't stay in Canada.
You see, Orozco says he's gay, and homosexuality is against the law in Nicaragua.
But Canadian officials turned down his request for asylum because they weren't convince that Orozco is gay.
Lorenda Reddekopp is covering the story in Toronto for the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation.
Lorenda, first, welcome to the program.
Thanks, Liane.
How did this young man wind up in Canada?
Well, it's quite a long journey that he took.
He's 22 years old now.
He started out in Nicaragua.
And then at the age of 12, he left Nicaragua, walking and hitch hiking, made his way all the way through Central America.
Then, ended up in Mexico for a while where he stayed with a Christian family for a time.
Then, he made it to the United States illegally and he was caught and was supposed to be deported, but he ended up staying with a Christian family there as well.
And in the end, he was actually in the United States for five years.
And then, finally, he made it to Canada.
And so how old was he when he made it to Canada?
He would have been 19 years old.
All right.
On what basis then did Canada's Immigration and Refugee Board conclude that he's not gay?
Well, he filed a refugee claim and then there was a hearing that took place in which there was one member of the Immigration and Refugee Board there.
And it was hearing by videoconference and that person decided that he just didn't prove that he was gay.
Now, the question a lot of us asked, of course, is well, how do you prove that you're gay?
It seems odd for all of us to think how do you prove that.

Speaking to his lawyer now, tells me it's things like, for example, if you're trying to plead refugee status on the basis of your religion, you show your - if there's some, sort of, card, if you have pictures, pictures from meeting with a group -well, he says that it's the same if you're trying to put it on the basis of your sexual orientation.

So, for example, he could have shown pictures if he went to the gay pride parade here in Toronto, for example, or apparently at the time, he had an Internet profile on some gay Web sites that could have been provided.
Different things like that.
At the time, however, he had a different lawyer who never gave any of that information.
You've met Alvaro Orozco.
Why does he not want to go back to Nicaragua?
I mean, we've mentioned that homosexuality is against the law in Nicaragua, but did he have - did he express to you other fears about going back?
Yes.
Well, I was determined to get something here, so I mentioned the famous saying that you can learn a lot about a person by what they eat.
Actually, I just made that up, but I think it's true.
So I quizzed him.
OK, Walter, President Bush, boiled or baked?
I would say boiled.
Sauteed or deep-fried?
I would probably say deep-fried.
Vanilla or chocolate?
Mm, that's a close one.
Chocolate, I would say.
Chicken or fish?
